page.title: 02WADENHOE CHURCH 1
page.content:
HISTORY OF THE BUILDING
The saddle-back late Norman tower is all that remains of a late twelfth century church.It has bell openings to the east and a small round-headed window. At the foot of the north wall are three blank arches, round and pointed in shape with leaf decoration. The present chancel and nave were built in the thirteenth century. The northern arcade dates from this period, but the south end is from the fourteenth century when the aisles seem to have been rebuilt and widened. At this time the clestory was added, the porch was erected and some alterations made in the tower. The circular font dates from about thirteenth century and is adorned with dogtooth, roses, stiff leafed foliage and two human heads.
